docs.title: 📝 Mini Style Guide
docs.text: This portfolio follows a simple, consistent writing style. The goal: clarity, consistency, and easy scanning.

docs.title: ✍️ Writing style
docs.text:
• Use short, direct sentences (aim for one idea per sentence).
  • Write in the active voice (e.g., Click Save, not The Save button should be clicked).
  • Address the reader with imperatives (“Click…”, “Select…”).
  • Use present tense for steps and descriptions.
  • One action per numbered step.

docs.title: 💻 Formatting rules
docs.text:
• Headings: Use emojis + plain titles (e.g., ## ⚡ Quick Start).
  • Bold for button names, menu paths, or anything the user must click.
  • Example: Click File → Export**
  • Italics for emphasis or placeholders.
  • Example: Enter your Project name**.
  • Code font for commands, file names, or text to type.
  • Example: Save as glossary.csv.

docs.title: 📷 Screenshots
docs.text:
• Crop tightly to show only the relevant area.
  • Add alt text for accessibility.
  • Example: ![Trados New Project wizard](trados-new-project.png)
  • Use arrows or boxes sparingly to highlight UI elements.

docs.title: 🔗 Linking
docs.text:
• Relative links inside the repo (e.g., (quick-start.md) not full URLs).
  • In overviews (README.md), always add a short description after each link.

docs.title: 📅 Maintenance
docs.text:
• Every doc ends with a Last updated line.
  • Add a short version note if content applies to a specific software release.
  • Example: > 🛈 Written using Trados Studio 2017.

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: 🌐 Getting Started with DeepL (Web App)
docs.text:
This mini-documentation set introduces the basics of working with DeepL Translator in the browser. It is designed for translators who want to use DeepL efficiently without needing a paid plan or installation.

🛈 Version note: Written using the DeepL free web app (September 2025). Features may differ in the desktop or Pro versions.

docs.title: 📂 What’s inside
docs.text:
• ⚡ Quick Start — Translate text and documents in 5 steps
  • 📘 How-To: Create and Use a Glossary — Control your terminology
  • 🔧 Troubleshooting — Common problems and fixes

docs.title: 🎯 Purpose
docs.text:
This guide shows how to: - Translate text and documents online - Apply terminology consistently with glossaries - Solve basic problems (e.g., file types, login, glossary limits)

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 Reference: DeepL Glossary Limits (Free vs Pro)
docs.text:
Glossary capacity depends on your DeepL plan.

Feature Free Plan Pro Plan Number of glossaries 1 Unlimited Entries per glossary 10 5,000+ Supported languages EN ↔ DE, FR, ES, IT, NL All supported pairs Edit glossary Yes Yes Import/export terms ❌ ✅ (CSV, TBX)

Source: DeepL Support

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 How to Use Glossaries (DeepL Web)
docs.text: Control terminology across your translations.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• DeepL account (Free or Pro)
  • Terms to enforce (e.g., product names)

docs.title: 1) Open the Glossary
docs.text:
1. In the DeepL interface, open Glossary (top bar).
  2. Choose a language pair for the glossary.
Glossary — add terms and translations, then Save.

docs.title: 2) Create or select a glossary
docs.text:
• Click New glossary (name it), or select an existing one.
  • Keep one glossary per language pair for clarity.

docs.title: 3) Add entries
docs.text:
1. Enter Term (source) and Translation (target).
  2. Click Save to add each pair.
  3. Repeat for all key terms.

docs.title: 4) Apply the glossary
docs.text:
• Make sure the glossary is selected/active when translating.
  • Type or paste text — terms should follow your glossary.
  • For files, the glossary applies when it’s active at upload time.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
Your translations follow your approved terminology.

See also: - Quick Start - Glossary limits

docs.title: ⚡ Quick Start: DeepL (Web)
docs.text: Translate text or files in minutes.

docs.title: Step 1 — Open DeepL
docs.text:
Go to DeepL and sign in (if you have a Pro account).

Start by typing text or click Translate files to upload a document.

docs.title: Step 2 — Translate text
docs.text:
1. Paste or type your text on the left.
  2. Choose the target language on the right.
  3. Copy or download the result.

Tip

For consistent terms, use a Glossary. See How to use glossaries.

docs.title: Step 3 — Translate a file
docs.text:
1. Click Translate files on the home screen.
  2. Choose your target language.
  3. Select your document (e.g., .docx, .pptx, .pdf).
  4. Download the translated file.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
You’ve translated text or documents. Next, add a glossary to control terminology.

See also: - How to use glossaries - Glossary limits

docs.title: 🔧 Troubleshooting: DeepL (Web App)
docs.text: Common problems when using the free DeepL translator in a browser, and how to solve them.

docs.title: 1) I can’t log in
docs.text: Cause: Wrong password or using Google/Apple login without linking it to a DeepL account. Fix: - Reset your password at https://www.deepl.com/account/reset-password. - If you usually log in with Google or Apple, make sure to click the matching button on the login screen.

docs.title: 2) My file won’t upload
docs.text: Cause: DeepL free supports only Word (.docx) and PowerPoint (.pptx). Fix: - Convert your file to .docx or .pptx before uploading. - For PDFs, use another tool to convert to Word first.

docs.title: 3) The file is too large
docs.text: Cause: Free accounts have a size limit per document. Fix: - Split the document into smaller sections. - Translate each separately. - Or upgrade to a paid plan for higher limits.

docs.title: 4) Glossary doesn’t apply
docs.text: Cause: Glossaries work only for supported language pairs (e.g., EN–DE, EN–FR). Fix: - Check that your source/target pair supports glossaries. - Make sure you’re logged in, since glossaries are linked to your account. - Free accounts allow only 10 entries — delete one if the glossary is full.

docs.title: 5) The translation is missing formatting
docs.text:
Cause: DeepL sometimes strips complex formatting. Fix: - Simplify the original file before uploading. - Reapply formatting manually after translation.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: DeepL — Create and Manage Glossaries
docs.text:
Learn how to create, populate, and use DeepL glossaries for consistent terminology.

Who is this for?

Translators and technical writers who need term consistency across projects.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• DeepL account (Free or Pro)
  • Browser access
  • Optional: API key (for the API example)

docs.title: Create a Glossary
docs.text:
Create a new glossary from DeepL's Glossary panel.
  1. Open DeepL and go to Glossaries.
  2. Click New glossary and provide a name and language pair.
  3. Click Create.

Naming convention

Use a project prefix (e.g., ACME_UI_en-de) to keep glossaries organized.

docs.title: Add Entries
docs.text:
You can add terms in two ways: - Manually (best for a few terms) - Using a file (best for many terms at once)

Add Manually
  1. Click Add entry.
  2. Enter the Source term and the Target term.
  3. (Optional) Add a Comment to explain special cases.
  4. Click Save.

When to use this

Use the manual option if you only need to add a handful of terms.

Upload from a File

DeepL also allows you to copy/paste a list of terms from a CSV file.

What is a CSV file? A CSV is just a simple text file where each line contains information separated by commas. For example:

source_term,target_term,comment
file,Datei,UI label
folder,Ordner,UI label
translate,übersetzen,verb form

When to use this

If you have dozens of terms, create a list in Excel or Google Sheets and export it as CSV. Then copy the lines into DeepL’s import box.

Bulk entry via CSV paste saves time for larger term sets.

docs.title: Use the Glossary in Translation
docs.text:
• Start a translation as usual.
  • Select your Glossary from the dropdown for the current language pair.
  • Terms will be replaced automatically according to your entries.

Note: If a term is not replaced, check the exact case and plural form.

docs.title: Export / Import (Reference)
docs.text:
Action Where to click Result Export Glossary → ••• → Export CSV Downloads CSV of entries Import Glossary → Add entries → CSV Appends entries

Footnote example: Glossary behavior may vary slightly across languages[^1].

[^1]: DeepL occasionally updates glossary handling for specific language pairs.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Glossary not visible?
  • Confirm the language pair matches your document.
  • Refresh the page after creating a new glossary.
CSV import failed
  • Ensure three columns: source, target, comment (optional but keep column).
  • Remove stray semicolons or tabs.

docs.title: Optional: API Example (Advanced)
docs.text:
If you have an API key, you can create a glossary programmatically.

```bash curl https://api-free.deepl.com/v2/glossaries \ -H "Authorization: DeepL-Auth-Key YOUR_API_KEY" \ -d "name=ACME_UI_en-de" \ -d "source_lang=EN" \ -d "target_lang=DE" \ --data-urlencode "entries=file,Datei\nfolder,Ordner\ntranslate,übersetzen"

docs.title: Guide to Installing VLC Media Player
Introduction
docs.text: This guide explains how to download and install VLC Media Player on your Windows computer. It is intended for beginners and anyone who wants a simple, reliable media player.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before you start, make sure you have: * A computer running Windows 10 or later. * An internet connection to download the installer. * Administrator rights on your computer to install software.

docs.title: 1. Download the Installer
docs.text: Navigate to the official VLC website at www.videolan.org. The website should automatically detect your operating system. Click the big orange "Download VLC" button.

docs.title: 2. Run the Installer
docs.text: Locate the downloaded file (usually in your Downloads folder and named vlc-*-win64.exe). Double-click the file to run it. If a User Account Control window appears, click "Yes" to allow the app to make changes to your device.

docs.title: 3. Follow the Installation Wizard
docs.text: The installation wizard will open. You can mostly use the default settings. Choose your preferred language, click "Next", review the license agreement, and click "Next" again. On the "Choose Components" screen, you can leave the default options selected. Click "Install" to begin the installation.

docs.title: 4. Finish the Installation
docs.text: Wait for the progress bar to complete. Once finished, ensure the box for "Run VLC" is checked and click "Finish" to exit the wizard and launch the program.

docs.title: Tips and Common Issues
docs.text:
• If the installer does not start, try right-clicking the file and selecting "Run as administrator".
  • A common issue is downloading the installer from a third-party website that bundles unwanted software. Always download VLC directly from videolan.org to avoid this.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
When you have completed these steps, you will be able to open VLC Media Player and play almost any video or audio file on your computer.

Author: Chafyn Hörnecke Last updated: 10.09.2025

docs.title: 🖋️ Getting Started with Trados Studio 2017
docs.text:
This mini-documentation set introduces the basics of working in Trados Studio 2017 for first-time users.

🛈 Version note: Written using Trados Studio 2017. Menu names or screens may differ slightly in newer versions.

docs.title: What’s inside
docs.text:
• ⚡ Quick Start
  • 📘 How-To: Create a Project
  • 🔧 Troubleshooting

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 📘 How to Access Help in Trados Studio 2017
Who this is for
docs.text: Translators who want to quickly find support, tutorials, or solutions while working in Trados Studio 2017.

docs.title: What you need
docs.text:
• SDL Trados Studio 2017 installed
  • Internet connection (for online resources)

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the Help ribbon
  2. At the top of the Trados window, click the Help tab.

  3. This ribbon is available in all views. ![Help tab open with Knowledge Base, Community and Support options](../assets/images/trados/help-ribbon.png){ width="900" } Help tab — links out to Knowledge Base, Community, and Support.

  4. Choose a help option

  5. Studio Blog → Articles and tips about using Trados.
  6. Knowledge Base (KB) → FAQs and troubleshooting guides.
  7. SDL Community → Online discussion forum with other users.
  8. Customer Feedback → Send feedback directly to SDL.

  9. Contact Support → Open the SDL TranslationZone support page.

  10. Download resources

  11. From the SDL TranslationZone, go to Learn & Support → Downloads.
  12. There you’ll find guides, updates, and additional tools.

docs.title: Change the UI language
docs.text:
If your Trados menus are not in English, switch the User interface language:

View → User interface language — select English, then restart Trados when prompted.

docs.title: Result
docs.text: You can now access official documentation, community forums, and SDL support directly from within Trados.

docs.title: If things go wrong
docs.text:
• The Help ribbon doesn’t appear: Make sure you are on the latest service pack for Trados Studio 2017.
  • Links don’t open: Check your internet connection or try opening them in a separate browser.

Last updated: 2 Sept 2025

docs.title: 🧭 How-To: Create a Project
docs.text: Set up a new Trados project using the wizard.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
• Your source files are ready (e.g., .docx, .txt).
  • You know your source and target language(s).
  • (Optional) You have a Translation Memory (TM) to reuse — or you’ll create one.

docs.title: 1) Start the wizard
docs.text:
From the Home tab, click New Project.

Home → New Project — starts the setup wizard.

docs.title: 2) Project Details
docs.text:
Name your project and choose where to save it.

Project Details — give the project a clear name and folder.

docs.title: 3) Language Pairs
docs.text:
Pick the source and target language(s).

Language Pairs — set the languages you’ll translate between.

docs.title: 4) Add Files
docs.text:
Add the documents you want to translate.

Add Files — select your source documents.

docs.title: 5) Translation Memories
docs.text:
Attach an existing TM or Create a new one (recommended if you don’t have one).

Translation Memories — reuse previous translations or start a new TM.

docs.title: 6) Finish
docs.text: Review the summary and click Finish. Trados creates the project and opens it in the Editor.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
Your project appears in Home → Projects and opens in the Editor ready to translate.

See also: - ⚡ Quick Start — the short version - 📘 How to Access Help — switch the UI language if needed

docs.title: ⌨️ Reference: Common Keyboard Shortcuts in Trados Studio 2017
docs.text:
Use these shortcuts to work faster in the Editor view.

Action Shortcut (Windows) Confirm segment Ctrl+Enter Insert translation from memory Ctrl+T Copy source to target Ctrl+Insert Navigate to next segment Ctrl+↓ Navigate to previous segment Ctrl+↑ Undo last action Ctrl+Z Redo Ctrl+Y Search in translation memory F3

🛈 Version note: Shortcuts may vary in later Trados versions.

Last updated: 4 Sept 2025

docs.title: ⚡ Quick Start: Trados Studio 2017
docs.text: Set up your first project in a few minutes.

docs.title: Step 1 — Open Trados Studio
docs.text:
When Trados opens, you land on the Home tab in the Projects view.

Home → Projects view — the normal starting point.

Alternative: drag & drop files

On some setups you may see the Get Started area on the Home tab where you can drag files for translation. That’s an alternative entry point:

Use Drag files for translation or click browse to choose files.

If your menus aren’t in English, see Change the UI language.

docs.title: Step 2 — Create your first project
docs.text:
1. Click New Project on the ribbon.
  2. In Project Details, enter a Project name and Location.
  3. Choose your source language and target language(s).
  4. Click Add Files and select your source documents (e.g., .docx, .txt).
  5. Add a translation memory (TM) — choose an existing one or click Create to make a new TM.
  6. Click Finish — Trados creates the project and opens it in the Editor.

docs.title: Screenshots (for Step 2)
docs.text:
Wizard — Language Pairs: set source and target languages. Home → New Project: click to start the wizard. Wizard — Add Files: select the files to translate.

Next: See How-To: Create a Project for more detail.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025

docs.title: 1) “New Project” is greyed out
docs.text: Likely cause: No license activated. Fix: Go to Help → Product Activation and activate your license.

docs.title: 2) My translation memory isn’t available
docs.text: Likely cause: TM wasn’t attached during setup. Fix: Open Project Settings → Language Pairs → Translation Memories → Add your TM.

docs.title: 3) I can’t open my source file
docs.text: Likely cause: Unsupported or disabled file type. Fix: File → Options → File Types → make sure the file type is enabled.

docs.title: 4) I don’t see termbase results
docs.text:
Likely cause: No termbase attached. Fix: Project Settings → Language Pairs → Termbases → Add a termbase.

Last updated: 3 Sept 2025
